title: MACEReports-mapping
text: Although functions generally require Longitude/Latitude (decimal degrees; henceforth referred x,y) arguments, re-project points nicer projection producing maps. default, Albers Equal Area Alaska (EPSG:3338). ’d prefer something else, possible (see help given function).

what: How do I plot these things?
title: MACEReports-mapping
text: functions create sticks interpolated plots return data forms can plotted however ’d like (base R plotting, ggplot, etc). Basemaps, however, ggplot-specific. Examples vignette use ggplot plotting.

title: MACEReports-mapping
text: make stickplot, ’ll need: x,y, abundance value (z). function build_sf_sticks return sticks sf (simple features) dataframe. sf dataframes can plotted easily using ggplot2, base r plot. default, ’ll get bar rotated 5 degrees vertical, scaled work plots. can specified differently using arguments rotation bar_scale (see ?build_sf_sticks details) Plotting sticks easy ggplot2::geom_sf():  related function produce legend go sticks, build_stick_legend: default, produces white legend placed bottom right corner plot, proper units standard plots biomss/nmi-2; defaults can modified needed (see ?build_stick_legend). legend can added plot (see ).
code: sticks = build_sf_sticks(x = shelikof_xyz$START_LONGITUDE, y = shelikof_xyz$START_LATITUDE, z = shelikof_xyz$BIOMASS_NM2) ggplot(sticks)+   geom_sf() stick_legend = build_stick_legend(stick_data = sticks)

title: MACEReports-mapping
text: course, far isn’t great way look data! need basemap. function get_basemap_layers returns background map uses either high-resolution bathymetric layer ’s appropriate surveys, simple contours user-specifed depths (.e. 100 m, 200 m). can also return variety commonly used layers including NMFS management areas, 3 NMI buffer regions,Steller Sea Lion exclusions. basemaps intended Bering Sea Gulf Alaska. just want basic map, can simply feed sticks dataframe just created function get_basemap_layers. produce land bathymetric layers encompass data. returns ggplot object. find wanting access layers without using ggplot plotting- complain, ’ll add functionality.
code: basemap = MACEReports::get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks) #plot it all: the basemap, the sticks, and the legend: basemap+   geom_sf(data = sticks, color = 'red')+   stick_legend

title: MACEReports-mapping
text: often present stickplots multiple groups (say, small fish big fish) separate sticks. can done `build_sf_sticks’:
code: #summarize the data by fish >=30 cm, <30 cm shelikof_by_size = shelikof_biomass%>%   filter(year == 2021)%>%   mutate(size_class = ifelse (LENGTH >= 30, 'big', 'small'))%>%   group_by(INTERVAL, size_class, START_LATITUDE, START_LONGITUDE)%>%   summarize(BIOMASS = sum(BIOMASS),             BIOMASS_NM2 = sum(BIOMASS_NM2))%>%   #cleanup: because we included intervals with zero pollock, the size class will be NA in those cases.    #remove those from this plot!   filter(!is.na(size_class))  #use the 'group_variable' argument in build_sf_sticks to build sticks for each group: sticks_by_size = build_sf_sticks(x = shelikof_by_size$START_LONGITUDE, y = shelikof_by_size$START_LATITUDE, z = shelikof_by_size$BIOMASS_NM2, group_variable = shelikof_by_size$size_class)  #plot everything again: basemap = MACEReports::get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks_by_size) stick_legend = build_stick_legend(stick_data = sticks_by_size)  basemap+   geom_sf(data = sticks_by_size, aes(color = size_class))+   stick_legend

title: MACEReports-mapping
text: bathymetry layer nice plots, inappropriate others. Want keep simple? Specify contours ’d like draw. options : 50, 100, 200, 300, 500, 700, 1000 (values M).  might also want include commonly used layer, NMFS management area 3nmi buffer around land areas. Great. See ?get_basemap_layers current options, ’s ’d add ones:  Since basemap just ggplot object, can add anything might want , change themes, etc.
code: basemap = MACEReports::get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks_by_size, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(100,200, 1000))  #view the plot basemap basemap = MACEReports::get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks_by_size, management_regions = TRUE, alaska_3nmi_buffer = TRUE)  #view the plot basemap basemap+   labs(title = 'Shelikof')+   theme(panel.border = element_blank())

title: MACEReports-mapping
text: sticks MACE favorite, often nice present interpolated map well. might want ? people think pseudo 3-d plots like stickplots bad (argument seems distort data therefore hard interpret). don’t totally agree , agree, interpolated plots another option display distribution abundance. Interpolated plots nice way compare distribution abundance time (lots information small panel). Creating interpolations requires make choices compared creating stickplots. limitations plots can made. Right now, can make maps following regions: ‘shelikof’, ‘summer_goa’, ‘core_ebs’, ‘sca’ (.e. Shelikof Strait winter survey, Summer GOA survey, Summer EBS survey, summer EBS survey within sea lion conservation area). must define domain interpolation. practical terms, means someone needs build polygon defines domain. want create interpolations elsewhere, can work add polygon . define resolution want interpolate. Smaller numbers = finer resolution (slower run times). value can thought distance meters interpolation points. 1000 seems work well Shelikof, 2500 seems fine larger regions. consider long want wait interpolation. ’ve generally using universal kriging latitude + longitude predictor variables, .e. formula like log10(abundance) ~ Lat + Long. works well can slow! estimated point function every observed point- case like EBS, can ~60,000 estimated points, estimated basis ~10,000 observations. can slow! Therefore, function includes options can produce similar output captures abundance distribution, less time. ’ve got options : Inverse Distance Weighting Ordinary Kriging (without local neighborhood estimation, see ) Universal kriging (without local neighborhood) Using local neighborhood (.e. number nearest observations use estimation) speeds things GREATLY seems capture trends estimating without limitation. Testing suggests best compromise speed helpful presentation abundance distribution use universal kriging local neighborhood 200 observations: Note function simply returns dataframe columns ‘x’, ‘y’, ‘z’. x y correspond positions interpolated values; z corresponds estimated value. default, x y coordinates Albers Equal Area projection (can changed out_crs argument get_interpolated_plot_vals), z log10-transformed abundance value (right now, can’t changed log10-transformed values seem highlight abundance distribution well data; change future versions folks dislike chosen transformation). x y points form grid; therefore, represents box equal size plotted raster.  course, basemap useful color scheme really help . Making basemap requires one additional step, comparison examples stickplots: current limitations functions written, must provide sf object get_basemap_layers function: ’ve got basemap, can add raster (, slightly upgraded color scheme):  additional function get_interpolated_color_bins bin colors make trends easier see. minimum, specify z value:  default, returns log10-sized bins; can modified using style argument get_interpolated_color_bins. See ?get_interpolated_color_bins options, kmeans tends work well. ##TODO: multiple years example, make scale even (.e. 10000-50000).
code: interp_vals_2021 = get_interpolated_plot_vals(x = shelikof_xyz$START_LONGITUDE, y = shelikof_xyz$START_LATITUDE, z = shelikof_xyz$BIOMASS, resolution = 1000, region = 'shelikof', interp_type = 'universal', neighborhood = 200) #> [1] "Interpolating using universal kridging; this can be very slow! Consider a higher resolution value if this is taking forever (recommended resolution for summer surveys >= 2500; for winter >= 1000"  #return a small table knitr::kable(head(interp_vals_2021), row.names = FALSE) ggplot()+   geom_raster(data = interp_vals_2021, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = z)) #create an sf object we can use to define the basemap extent extent = st_as_sf(interp_vals_2021, coords = c('x', 'y'), crs = 'EPSG:3338')  #use this to return the basemap; return a simple basemap with contours as the bathymetery seems too busy with interpolated maps basemap = get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = extent, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(100,200,1000)) basemap+   geom_raster(data = interp_vals_2021, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = z))+   scale_fill_viridis_c(option = 'magma') interp_vals_2021$plot_col = get_interpolated_color_bins(z = interp_vals_2021$z)  basemap+   geom_raster(data = interp_vals_2021, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = plot_col))+   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = 'magma')

title: build_biomass_at_age_table_summer_goa — build_biomass_at_age_table_summer_goa
text: Build pollock biomass--age table used summer GOA reports. report biomass age ages 1- maximum reported age survey, report number (.e. survey region) defined analysis.

title: build_biomass_at_age_table_summer_goa — build_biomass_at_age_table_summer_goa
text: biomass_nums_age_data name dataframe contains pollock biomass--age data; dataframe created cruise report markdown process using function get_biomass_and_nums_age_data_function.R; provides data used create 'current survey /pollock ' dataframe named current_survey_pollock_biomass_nums_age. dataframe easiest input build_biomass_at_age_table_summer_goa function.

text: list two items: item 1 Flextable table object, item 2 table caption.

text: Mike Levine

title: build_biomass_at_age_table_winter_goa — build_biomass_at_age_table_winter_goa
text: Build pollock biomass--age table used winter GOA reports. data used usually limited 'selectivity-corrected era' within Shelikof Strait (.e. 2008-current). function report ages 1-18, region defined analysis. especially old age class (>18 years old), table report age opposed nomimal age 1- age 18 range.

text: biomass_nums_age_data name dataframe contains abundance--age values; dataframe created cruise report markdown process using function get_biomass_and_nums_age_data_function.R; provides data used create dataframe named shelikof_sel_corr_surveys_biomass_nums_age. dataframe easiest input build_biomass_at_age_table_winter_goa function. region_name name reporting region want include table (generally "Shelikof Strait" winter GOA reports)

title: build_sf_sticks — build_sf_sticks
text: Accepts xyz data (example, longitude/latitude/abundance) returns vertical 'stick' position. Sticks returned sf LINESTRING objects. objects can plotted using ggplot2::geom_sf() base plot. #'

title: build_sf_sticks — build_sf_sticks
code: build_sf_sticks(   x,   y,   z,   group_variable = NULL,   return_df = NULL,   rotation = 5,   bar_scale = 0.5,   crs = "EPSG:3338" )

title: build_sf_sticks — build_sf_sticks
text: x x- position y Y- position z Abundance value (value used scale sticks) group_variable specified, specify group stick; can used identify sticks group. return_df specified, include columns original dataframe returned object. one 'group_variable' 'return_df' specified. rotation Rotation sticks degrees vertical. Default 5 degrees. 0 = rotation; positive values rotate bars clockwise direction. bar_scale relative size sticks. Default ~1/2 total plot height. crs specified, coordinate reference system (CRS) sticks projected. relies sf::st_crs function- make sure using valid CRS argument. specified, CRS provided.

title: build_sf_sticks — build_sf_sticks
code: dat = data.frame('x' = c(-152.2, -150.3, -159.4), 'y' = c(55.2, 55.8, 55.6), 'z' = c(7500,40000, 28000), 'species' = c('a', 'a', 'b'))  #sticks can be plotted with ggplot2::geom_sf(), #and Coordinate Reference System (CRS) conversions are handled by sf::st_crs() library(ggplot2) #> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.2.1 library(sf) #> Warning: package 'sf' was built under R version 4.2.1 #> Linking to GEOS 3.9.1, GDAL 3.4.3, PROJ 7.2.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE  #you have to provide x,y,z at minimum sticks = build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z)  #plot with ggplot2 geom_sf() ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = sticks)   #or with base r plotting plot(dat)   #the rotation (from 0) can be specified (in degrees from 0-360). If not specified, #sticks will be rotated to 5 degrees sticks = build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z, rotation = 15)  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = sticks)   #If a CRS is not specified, none will be assigned; if one is specified, #it will be set using sf st_crs() sticks = build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z, rotation = 15, crs = 3338,                          group_variable = dat$species)  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = sticks, aes(color = species))   #sticks are automatically scaled so that the largest abundance value #this can be modified with bar_scale argument sticks =  build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z, rotation = -5, bar_scale = 2) sticks2 = build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z, rotation = 5, bar_scale = .5)  ggplot() +  geom_sf(data = sticks)+  geom_sf(data = sticks2)

title: build_stick_legend — build_stick_legend

code: build_stick_legend(   stick_data,   legend_pos = "right",   legend_color = "white",   legend_label = NULL )

title: build_stick_legend — build_stick_legend
text: stick_data 'stick' dataframe returned build_sf_sticks. legend_pos One 'right' 'left'; legend bar placed corresponding corner. legend_color Default white standard MACE basemaps; specify alternates standard ggplot-compatible formats legend_label Defaults label standard MACE units (t/nmi^2); specify alternate needed reflect units

title: build_stick_legend — build_stick_legend
code: library(ggplot2) library(sf)  dat = data.frame('x' = c(-152.2, -150.3, -159.4), 'y' = c(55.2, 55.8, 55.6), 'z' = c(75000,400000, 280000), 'species' = c('a', 'a', 'b')) sticks = build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z, rotation = 15, crs = 3338) legend = build_stick_legend(stick_data = sticks, legend_pos = 'left', legend_color = 'black') ggplot()+   geom_sf(data = sticks)+   legend

title: Create the standard MACE target strength relationships table — build_ts_relationships_table
text: Produce TS-length relationships table use standard MACE cruise reports. stores commonly used TS-length relationships, need updated add TS-length relationships analyses. Note formatted use MS Word output, references formatted use .bib bibliography file. Standard cruise reports include appropriate .bib file.

title: Create the standard MACE target strength relationships table — build_ts_relationships_table
Create the standard MACE target strength relationships table — build_ts_relationships_table
text: ts_relationships_used optional character vector relationships used survey. used, attempt limit table values used survey. Current options available : macebase2.ts_relationships; straightforward way specify use ts_relationships_data$TS_RELATIONSHIP vector returned get_ts_relationships function generated get_macebase_data step report generation.

title: Create the standard MACE target strength relationships table — build_ts_relationships_table
text: list two items: item 1 Flextable table object, item 2 table caption.

title: Create the standard MACE target strength relationships table — build_ts_relationships_table
text: Mike Levine

title: Create the standard MACE target strength relationships table — build_ts_relationships_table
code: if (FALSE) { #build a table for all commonly used TS relationships ts_table_list = build_ts_relationships_table()  #return table and caption ts_table = ts_table_list[[1]] ts_caption = ts_table_list[[2]]  #limit based on the relationships used (see macebase2.ts_relationships) ts_relationships_list = c('standard_pollock', 'chrysaora_melanaster', 'euphausiids_15_65mm_38khz')  ts_table_list = build_ts_relationships_table(ts_relationships_used = ts_relationships_list)  #return table and caption ts_table = ts_table_list[[1]] ts_caption = ts_table_list[[2]] }

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
text: Returns base map. map returned ggplot2 object complex maps can built top . provides land, bathymetry, , optionally, variety common layers including NMFS management areas, 3 NMI buffer regions,Steller Sea Lion exclusions. basemaps intended Bering Sea Gulf Alaska. layer slightly larger extent plot_limits_data; users still use ggplot2::coord_sf fine-tune plot extent.

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
code: get_basemap_layers(   plot_limits_data,   bathy = TRUE,   contours = NULL,   management_regions = NULL,   SSL_critical_habitat = NULL,   alaska_3nmi_buffer = NULL,   land_fill_color = "#616161",   land_outline_color = "black" )

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
text: plot_limits_data sf spatial dataframe; required used define base map extent projection. bathy default, bathymetric baselayer based GEBCO (https://www.gebco.net/) gridded bathymetric dataset included basemap; FALSE, bathymetric baselayer included contours Provide contour lines requested depths. Specify depths positive numeric values, .e. c(200,100,50) management_regions TRUE, add NMFS management regions basemap SSL_critical_habitat TRUE, add Steller Sea Lion critical habitat buffers basemap alaska_3nmi_buffer TRUE, add ADFG 3 nmi management buffer basemap land_fill_color like different fill color landmasses, specify required ggplot2. land_outline_color like different outline color landmasses, specify required ggplot2.

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
text: list class ggplot containing information required plotting basemap.

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
text: Mike Levine

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
code: if (FALSE) { library(ggplot2) library(sf) library(MACEReports)  dat = data.frame('x' = c(-152.2, -150.3, -159.4), 'y' = c(55.2, 55.8, 55.6), 'z' = c(7500,40000, 28000), 'species' = c('a', 'a', 'b'))  #create an sf dataframe dat = sf::st_as_sf(dat, coords = c('x', 'y'), crs = 4326) #convert CRS to a reasonable projection dat = sf::st_transform(dat, crs = 'EPSG:3338')  #return the basemap as a ggplot layer mace_basemap = get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat)  #note that this basemap will replace the usual call to ggplot() as the start of your plot: mace_basemap+  geom_sf(data = dat, aes(color = species))  #You can add other commonly used MACE layers to the basemap mace_basemap = get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat, management_regions = TRUE) mace_basemap  mace_basemap = get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat, alaska_3nmi_buffer = TRUE) mace_basemap  mace_basemap = get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat, SSL_critical_habitat = TRUE) mace_basemap  mace_basemap = get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(200, 100, 50)) mace_basemap }

title: get_interpolated_color_bins — get_interpolated_color_bins
text: Return binned abundance data plotting interpolated values greater contrast. wrapper around classInt::classIntervals function make easier return binned color values.

title: get_interpolated_color_bins — get_interpolated_color_bins
text: z vector abundance values n_bins number bins like return; default 9. ignored style 'log10'. style algorithm used binning; default 'log10', places abundance values log10 bins; 'kmeans' also produces good results. nice_labels return label values linear (vs log) space formatted use plots; meant #' used conjunction values generated get_interpolated_plot_vals, return log10 units.

title: get_interpolated_color_bins — get_interpolated_color_bins
text: Mike Levine

title: get_interpolated_plot_vals — get_interpolated_plot_vals
text: Accepts xyz data (example, longitude/latitude/abundance) returns dataframe interpolated values. number interpolated values returned depends chosen map resolution. objects can plotted using neighborhoodbase plot, converted rasters.

title: get_interpolated_plot_vals — get_interpolated_plot_vals
code: get_interpolated_plot_vals(   x,   y,   z,   resolution,   region,   out_crs = "EPSG:3338",   interp_type,   neighborhood = NULL )

title: get_interpolated_plot_vals — get_interpolated_plot_vals
text: x Longitude (decimal degrees) y Latitude (decimal degrees) z Abundance value resolution Distance (meters) interpolation points. Recommended values 1000 Shelikof, 2500 summer surveys. region Region make interpolations. Currently, options 'shelikof', 'summer_goa', 'core_ebs', 'sca'. out_crs Coordinate Reference Setting returned interpolation points; default "EPSG:3338" interp_type Interpolation formula apply. Options 'universal', 'ordinary', 'idw'. Universal uses universal kridging Latitude Longitude variables; Ordinary ordinary kridging 'neighborhood' 100 observations used every estimation point, idw performs inverse-distance weighting interpolation. Universal kridging comprehensive, slow. IDW coarse, fast. neighborhood (optional) number nearest observations use universal ordinary kridging calculations. default use observations; limiting calculations neighborhood can used speed interpolation. argument passes number nearest arguments use  Gstat::kridge; see Gstat::kridge nmax argument details.

title: get_interpolated_plot_vals — get_interpolated_plot_vals
text: dataframe 4 columns: x = Longitude (crs specified out_crs; default default "EPSG:3338") y = Latitude (crs specified out_crs; default default "EPSG:3338") z = abundance value. Note values default Log 10-transformed abundance, tend highlight patterns abundance distribution MACE datasets.

title: get_interpolated_plot_vals — get_interpolated_plot_vals
text: Mike Levine

title: get_interpolated_plot_vals — get_interpolated_plot_vals
code: if (FALSE) { preds_vals = get_interpolated_plot_vals(x = plot_data$START_LONGITUDE, y = plot_data$START_LATITUDE, z = plot_data$BIOMASS, resolution = 2500, region = 'summer_goa', interp_type = 'universal') }

title: template_df_specimen_data_summer_goa — template_df_specimen_data_summer_goa
text: data frame 5 rows 14 columns: SHIP ship number (numeric) SURVEY survey number (numeric) HAUL haul number; EVENT_ID used elsewhere (numeric) SPECIES_CODE RACE species code (numeric) COMMON_NAME species common name (character) SCIENTIFIC_NAME species scientific name (character) PARTITION net partition catch (codend, pocketnet, etc; character) ORGANISM_WEIGHT individual organism weight (numeric) SEX organism sex (character) MATURITY maturity stage (character) OTOLITH_TAKEN 1 otolith collected; 0 otherwise (numeric) AGE organism age (numeric) organism_length organism length- note length type included (numeric) length_type length type: FORK_LENGTH, STANDARD_LENGTH, TOTAL_LENGTH, MANTLE_LENGTH, BELL_DIAMETER,   CARAPACE_LENGTH, WING_SPAN, PREANAL_FIN_LENGTH (character) @source Template dateset gathered using get_specimen_table_data.R function Summer 2021 GOA Cruise Report

title: template_df_specimen_table_summer_goa — template_df_specimen_table_summer_goa

title: template_df_specimen_table_summer_goa — template_df_specimen_table_summer_goa
text: #' @format data frame 5 rows 14 columns: HAUL haul number; EVENT_ID used elsewhere (numeric) POLLOCK_CATCH_LENGTHS number pollock lengths per haul (numeric) POLLOCK_WEIGHTS number pollock weights per haul (numeric) MATURITIES number pollock maturities per haul (numeric) OTOLITHS number pollock otoliths collected per haul (numeric) O_TAKEN number pollock ovaries sampled per haul (numeric) CAPELIN_CATCH_LENGTHS number pacific capelin lengths per haul (numeric) CAPELIN_WEIGHTS number pacific capelin weights per haul (numeric) POP_CATCH_LENGTHS number pacific ocean perch lengths per haul (numeric) POP_WEIGHTS number pacific ocean perch weights per haul (numeric) OTHER_CATCH_LENGTHS number species (pollock/capelin/POP) lengths per haul (numeric) OTHER_WEIGHTS number species (pollock/capelin/POP) weights per haul (numeric) SURVEY survey number (numeric) region Survey region name (character) #' @source Template dateset gathered using get_specimen_table_data.R function Summer 2021 GOA Cruise Report
